meaning_mnemonic:
The thing your <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>request</kanji>s is what your heart wants. This is your <vocabulary>heartfelt desire</vocabulary>.

心願 is often found in the phrase 心願成就 (fulfillment of a heartfelt wish), commonly used in the context of prayer rituals at Shinto shrines or Buddhist temples.

You 取り (take) and then 分け (divide) something. But you'll want to be <vocabulary>especially</vocabulary> careful not to give anyone an unequal share. This is especially important because we’re dealing with money, and people will flip out and shoot you under the table if you aren't especially accurate.

Note that this word is usually written in kana.

A <kanji>woman</kanji>'s <kanji>rights</kanji> consist of <vocabulary>women's rights</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word that is often used at the beginning of compounds, such as 女権拡張運動 (movement for the expansion of women's rights). In everyday conversations, you can just say 女性の権利 to talk about women’s rights.
The <kanji>peak</kanji> of the mountain is a <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mountain</vocabulary>.

This is an intransitive version of 擦る, so it means <vocabulary>to be rubbed</vocabulary>. It often implies damage, in which case it can mean <vocabulary>to be grazed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be scraped</vocabulary>, like when your knee gets grazed against a rough wall.

<kanji>Ten thousand</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, <vocabulary>banzai</vocabulary>!

万歳 is a cheerful word used to shout "<vocabulary>hooray</vocabulary>!" when celebrating something good. Because it's usually said with both arms raised, the action of <vocabulary>raising one's arms</vocabulary> can also be referred to as 万歳. This is often used when talking to children, like when telling them to raise their arms to take off a shirt.

And since raising your hands can also mean "<vocabulary>I give up</vocabulary>" in Japan, 万歳 can sometimes mean that as well. So basically, it's either "Yay, we did it!" or "That's it, I'm done." It really covers all your bases!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>zero</kanji>, but the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to spill something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drop something</vocabulary>. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach <kanji>zero</kanji>.
眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is <vocabulary>view</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scene</vocabulary>. It's what you're staring at.
Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it <vocabulary>to moisten</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to dampen</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Smash</kanji>ed <kanji>stone</kanji> is smashed stone. It's <vocabulary>rubble</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>broken stone</vocabulary>.
To <kanji>powder</kanji> I will <kanji>smash</kanji> it! If I do that, it's <vocabulary>pulverization</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>smashing</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sticky</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be sticky</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to persevere</vocabulary>, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.
<kanji>Sticky</kanji> <kanji>earth</kanji> is <vocabulary>clay</vocabulary>. Just think about feeling the clay. It's sticky especially when fresh and kind of wet, right?

If something <kanji>sticky</kanji> <kanji>wears</kanji> something else on it, it will stick together because there's <vocabulary>adhesion</vocabulary> between them.

粘着 refers to the adhesive properties of a material, especially in compound words like 粘着テープ (adhesive tape). On its own, it often describes the behavior of people who can't let go of a particular issue and keep on about it in unwanted ways.
<kanji>Change</kanji> your face with <kanji>cosmetics</kanji>! This is via <vocabulary>makeup</vocabulary> or, of course, <vocabulary>cosmetics</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deceit</kanji>, so when you're doing deceit, you are going <vocabulary>to deceive</vocabulary> someone.

If there are <kanji>lie</kanji>s and <kanji>deceit</kanji> in your interactions with people, you're committing <vocabulary>fraud</vocabulary>, you're carrying out a <vocabulary>scam</vocabulary>, you're <vocabulary>swindling</vocabulary>.

You use your <kanji>lie</kanji> to <kanji>take</kanji> what you want. That's when you <vocabulary>swindle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>defraud</vocabulary> someone to get their stuff. How dare you!

詐取 refers to the act of fraudulently obtaining something, typically money or property, through deceptive practices. This term is formal and often used in legal contexts.

If you <kanji>lie</kanji> about your <kanji>title</kanji>, the title which represents who you are, then that is a <vocabulary>misrepresentation</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>false statement</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>black</kanji> <kanji>fog</kanji> is going to be a really <vocabulary>thick fog</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>black veil</vocabulary> that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking.
<kanji>Morning</kanji> <kanji>fog</kanji> is <vocabulary>morning fog</vocabulary>, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>willow</kanji> for some reason is a <vocabulary>red light district</vocabulary>. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.

A <kanji>river</kanji> of <kanji>willow</kanji>s... so hilarious! What a great <vocabulary>comic haiku</vocabulary>, that one is. Try to think of a comic haiku about the river willow, if you can.

The River Willow
Flows upstream like a salmon
This is not funny

The place with <kanji>Italy</kanji> <kanji>force</kanji> is a place known as <vocabulary>Ise</vocabulary>. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet.

What does <kanji>Italy</kanji> <kanji>attain</kanji> like no other? <vocabulary>Flamboyance</vocabulary>! They redefine <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stylishness</vocabulary>, dazzling everyone with their unabashed display.

This word isn’t just about fashion; it's also for flamboyant, attention-grabbing actions. While it's an old-fashioned word, you still find it in phrases like 伊達眼鏡 (fashion glasses) or 伊達に〜はしていない (not doing something for show).
A <kanji>supplement</kanji> of <kanji>help</kanji> is an <vocabulary>aid</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>help</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assistance</vocabulary>. Not a full on help, but an aid of sorts.
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>help</kanji> is a <vocabulary>colonel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>navy captain</vocabulary>. They go around the seas, helping people in need by fighting the bad guys.

The <kanji>few</kanji> who <kanji>help</kanji> are the <vocabulary>major</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>lieutenant commander</vocabulary>s. They are the few who step up to the plate to help out in the army, according to this word's kanji.

The <kanji>middle</kanji> <kanji>help</kanji> in the army or navy is the <vocabulary>lieutenant colonel</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>navy commander</vocabulary>. I'm guessing these ranks are kind of in the middle or middle high end of the ranking scales?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>scroll</kanji> of <kanji>shaku</kanji>. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A <vocabulary>tape measure</vocabulary>!

If something is <kanji>pathetic</kanji> then you should have <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> on it. You should also feel a little <vocabulary>sorrow</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grief</vocabulary> for it, because seriously, so pathetic!

A <kanji>possible</kanji> <kanji>pathetic</kanji> scenario you might <kanji>imagine</kanji> is probably not just possibly pathetic. It's downright <vocabulary>pitiful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pathetic</vocabulary>, for sure.
I am <kanji>sad</kanji> and <kanji>pathetic</kanji> in how I feel. Such a deep <vocabulary>sorrow</vocabulary>! Such <vocabulary>grief</vocabulary> from my sad pathetic feelings.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>bottom</kanji> <kanji>lip</kanji> is your <vocabulary>lower lip</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bottom lip</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>above</kanji> <kanji>lip</kanji> is the <vocabulary>upper lip</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>soil</kanji> <kanji>fence</kanji> is a fence made from soil. Usually this is in the form of a <vocabulary>mud wall</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>earthen wall</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>attack</kanji> that causes a <kanji>crash</kanji> is when you're <vocabulary>shooting down</vocabulary> something, usually an aircraft.

If you <kanji>crash</kanji> and <kanji>fall</kanji> then you're <vocabulary>crashing</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>falling</vocabulary>, or maybe both.

墜落 refers to falling from a height and ending with a crash, like an airplane or a satellite plummeting to the ground.

You <kanji>lack</kanji> <kanji>likeness</kanji> to anything out there. You totally <vocabulary>lack</vocabulary> something that gives you likeness. It's a <vocabulary>deficiency</vocabulary>, or something.

When something bears a <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>likeness</kanji>, we say it happens <vocabulary>suddenly</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>all of a sudden</vocabulary>.

Note that this word is relatively formal and somewhat literary.
An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>old woman</kanji> is just an <vocabulary>old woman</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>old woman</kanji>, even with an honorific and an お is still an <vocabulary>elderly woman</vocabulary>. She might be your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary> as well, though, so be nice!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>cloth</kanji> <kanji>towel</kanji> is just a cloth towel. Essentially it's known as a <vocabulary>dish cloth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tea towel</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>miscellaneous</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dust cloth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>house cloth</vocabulary>. It's just a cloth that you use on random things.
A <kanji>hat</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cap</vocabulary>. Sadly, it's not made from children, unless you're crazy.

The <kanji>freight</kanji> of <kanji>cash</kanji> comes in. What is a freight of cash? It's just <vocabulary>money</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>currency</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>coinage</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Paper</kanji> <kanji>cash</kanji> is <vocabulary>paper money</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>grudge</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hold a grudge</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>pain</kanji> <kanji>grudge</kanji> is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my <vocabulary>regret</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hate</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to hate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to detest</vocabulary>.
If you have <kanji>love</kanji> and <kanji>hate</kanji> then you have <vocabulary>love and hate</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rest</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rest</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>rest</kanji> <kanji>rest</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rest</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>break</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>recess</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>folding fan</kanji> and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means <vocabulary>to fan</vocabulary> instead.

A <kanji>folding fan</kanji> <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is a machine that blows wind like a folding fan. That's an <vocabulary>electric fan</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>electronic fan</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>folding fan</kanji>'s <kanji>child</kanji> is, for some reason, a <vocabulary>folding fan</vocabulary>. I'm guessing there are different sizes of folding fans, and this is the smaller more manageable kind you can carry around easily and make it smaller by folding it up, which is why it's the "child" version of the folding fan. Still a folding fan, though.

Like the kanji, this means <vocabulary>door</vocabulary>.

You've already learned 戸 (door), but 扉 is a bit different. While 戸 can refer to any kind of door (though often sliding ones), 扉 more specifically refers to a <vocabulary>hinged door</vocabulary>, including things like gates or panels that open on hinges.

Because 扉 evokes the image of a door that swings open, it's also sometimes used metaphorically. For example, a book's front page can be called a 扉, and you'll see expressions like 心の扉 (the door to one's heart) too.

What are <kanji>gate</kanji> <kanji>door</kanji>s? The <vocabulary>doors of a gate</vocabulary>, though we may still just call them a <vocabulary>gate</vocabulary> in English.

門扉 is a formal word you'll encounter more often in writing or architecture talk. It usually refers specifically to the part of the gate that slides or swings open (in other words, its doors).
If you <kanji>insert</kanji> a <kanji>picture</kanji> into a book, it becomes a <vocabulary>book illustration</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Insert</kanji> some extra <kanji>talk</kanji>ing into a story, and you have a <vocabulary>side story</vocabulary>!

挿話 is a relatively formal word that refers to a short <vocabulary>anecdote</vocabulary> or little <vocabulary>episode</vocabulary> inserted into a story that isn't essential to the main narrative but adds some additional context, background, or flavor.
If you <kanji>insert</kanji> and <kanji>enter</kanji> something, you are doing <vocabulary>insertion</vocabulary> to it.

The kanji means <kanji>palm</kanji>, and so does the vocab! This is your <vocabulary>palm</vocabulary>, as in the <vocabulary>palm of one's hand</vocabulary>.

Something to note here is that you'll typically see "palm" in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing.

Who's the person with the <kanji>car</kanji> in the <kanji>palm</kanji> of their hand? The 車 here actually comes from 電車 (train), so this person is the <vocabulary>train conductor</vocabulary>. Think about it — the <vocabulary>conductor</vocabulary> handles things like checking tickets, making announcements, and giving signals to the driver, so everything that happens on the train is quite literally in their hands… er, palms. 

Note that these days, even many Japanese people get the 車掌 mixed up with the 運転士 (driver). However, the 車掌 is not the person driving the train — they're more like the train's overall supervisor, in charge of managing passengers and overseeing safety.
Put something in your <kanji>palm</kanji> and <kanji>grip</kanji> it. Now it's in your grasp — you're <vocabulary>grasping</vocabulary> it.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drip</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to drip</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>drip</kanji> is a <vocabulary>drop of water</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>water drop</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Point</kanji> <kanji>drip</kanji>s are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an <vocabulary>intravenous drip</vocabulary>. 

Back in the day this was a way of talking about raindrops, or really any falling drops of water. But nowadays we only use it for <vocabulary>IV drip</vocabulary>s.
A <kanji>self</kanji> <kanji>cook</kanji> is <vocabulary>cooking for oneself</vocabulary>. Better break out the TV tray.

A <kanji>cook</kanji>ing <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is just the act of <vocabulary>cooking</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>kitchen work</vocabulary>. 

炊事 refers to tasks involved in meal preparation as part of everyday life. It's a relatively formal word and not as commonly used as 料理, but you might see it used in lists of household chores or duties, like in a job description for a housekeeper.
A <kanji>cook</kanji> <kanji>food</kanji> <kanji>container</kanji> is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a <vocabulary>rice cooker</vocabulary>.

This is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>refreshing</vocabulary> as well.

爽やか generally describes something light, pleasant, and uplifting. You can use it for things like a cool morning breeze, the refreshing scent of fruit, or even a person who gives off a clean-cut and charming impression.

The 〜 shows the number of tatami mats, and the 畳 part is "tatami" of course. So, this is a <vocabulary>counter for tatami mats</vocabulary>. It is generally used to show how big an apartment or something is. Oh, your apartment is 12 tatami mats? Nice and big!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Something that is <kanji>bright</kanji> and <kanji>clear</kanji> has great <vocabulary>clarity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clearness</vocabulary>. Just look at something with such brightness and such clearness! It has so much clarity!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Divide</kanji>able <kanji>chopsticks</kanji> are chopsticks you can split apart. They are <vocabulary>splittable chopsticks</vocabulary>, almost always made from wood of some kind.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Your <kanji>torso</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> is the body area that's your torso. It's your <vocabulary>body</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>trunk</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>torso</vocabulary>, depending on what kind of body you have.

The kanji means <kanji>wick</kanji> and this word also means <vocabulary>wick</vocabulary>, but it means things at the <vocabulary>core</vocabulary> of other long things more often. Things like <vocabulary>pencil lead</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>marrow</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Rainbow</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji>ed things are <vocabulary>rainbow colored</vocabulary>.

Adding an お in front and a さん behind <kanji>miss</kanji> makes for a very respectful way of addressing a<vocabulary>young lady</vocabulary>. It can also be used to refer to somebody’s <vocabulary>daughter</vocabulary> in a polite manner.

Note that older generations tend to use this word to directly address a young woman. But be careful when doing this yourself, as it might come across as overly formal!
If you have a <kanji>naked</kanji> <kanji>foot</kanji>, it means you're not wearing anything on your foot, making you <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary>.
稼ぐ is "to earn income." This is the noun version. It's just <vocabulary>earnings</vocabulary>, the things you earn.
You know that 狩り is hunting already. This is the same thing (<vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing.
磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your <kanji>teeth</kanji> you are brushing them. That's why this is <vocabulary>to brush one's teeth</vocabulary>.

澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you <reading>mus</reading>t (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or <vocabulary>to make something clear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to clear something</vocabulary>.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to strain</vocabulary> when used together with 耳, as in 耳を澄ます, "to strain one's ears".
A <kanji>lump</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game <vocabulary>Katamari Damacy</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>spear</kanji> <kanji>ahead</kanji> is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the <vocabulary>point of spear</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>spearpoint</vocabulary>.

陰 is a shadow, and adding お to it and makes it honorific. It becomes the shadow of someone very important, and means <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary>, as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." This originally comes from the idea of being in the shadow of the gods, who are protecting you and helping you out!

If that's hard to remember, think about shade helping you out. Perhaps <vocabulary>thanks to</vocabulary> the <kanji>shade</kanji> you were able to survive the heat of the desert.
<kanji>Sticky</kanji> <kanji>sticky</kanji> things are really <vocabulary>sticky</vocabulary> and covered with <vocabulary>stickiness</vocabulary>.
What do you get when you <kanji>roast</kanji> <kanji>mochi</kanji>? <vocabulary>Senbei</vocabulary>, a crispy Japanese <vocabulary>rice cracker</vocabulary>!

When you <kanji>roast</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji>, you get <vocabulary>green tea</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>green leaf tea</vocabulary>or <vocabulary>sencha</vocabulary>.

In reality there are various ways to make green tea, but for the purposes of this mnemonic, let's imagine it's always roasted!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>carve</kanji> and the verb version is <vocabulary>to carve something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to engrave something</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning it can take a direct object. You engrave letters into a stone, and you carve a scary face into a pumpkin. Those letters and that face are your objects.
If <kanji>sand</kanji> makes a lot of <kanji>profit</kanji>, it swells up and becomes <vocabulary>gravel</vocabulary>. They're like the fat cats of the beach.

One's <kanji>parent</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji> is simply just <vocabulary>one's father</vocabulary>. 

Note that 親父 has a masculine and somewhat vulgar tone to it. It can refer to your own dad, someone else's, or a <vocabulary>middle-aged man</vocabulary> you're friendly with. When not talking about your own father, you'll want to add a さん at the end, making it 親父さん.
